node.title: Animation in Paraview is too quick
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Developers,
I have generated the exodus file for Porousflow tutorial11 but having an issue with how it plays in Paraview. The file plays okay but very fast compared to the very slow simulation/animation that is described on the moose webpage. I tried using the real-time mode and changing the iteration time length, but it didn’t work. Here is my file: Any help or guidance? Thanks.

Hello
You may run more time steps to have a slower video, or you can change the animation parameter of Paraview
https://discourse.paraview.org/t/how-to-change-frame-rate/3623 (this is what you tried, but it should work)
The file did not get attached to the post btw
Guillaume
It worked! thanks!

node.title: Smagorinsky model: grad_u or strain rate tensor?
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I've been looking into the existing INSADSmagorinskyEddyViscosity kernel, with a view to try implementing Van Driest damping in the future.
I'm no expert in turbulence modelling and LES, and am having trouble understanding the term which is added to the momentum equation for this kernel. In the documentation, I believe this Reynolds stress term is:
$\nabla\cdot\left ( -\nu_{SGS}\rho\nabla\overrightarrow{u} \right )$
From my own reading, I would expect the sub-grid scale viscosity to be multiplied by the strain rate tensor, rather than grad_u. Generally speaking, I was under the impression that shear stress in a newtonian fluid is proportional to the strain rate, which in 3D is not necessarily the same as the velocity gradient.
I have also encountered a derivation for Reynolds stresses which leads to the following:
$\tau_{SGS} = 2\rho\nu_{SGS}(S_{ij}-\frac{1}{3}\frac{\partial u_{k}}{\partial x_{k}}\delta_{ij}) - \frac{2}{3}\rho k_{SGS}\delta_{ij}$
Where $\delta_{ij}$ is Kronecker delta. I gather the additional terms on the RHS, besides the strain rate tensor, are correcting for some error which would otherwise be associated with this approach. How $\nu_{SGS}$ is determined differs depending on which turbulence model is being implemented. For the Smagorinsky model, we would define the sub-grid scale viscosity as in the documentation, and substitute into this equation to find the Reynolds stress term.
I'm hoping someone can help reconcile these different approaches: Viscosity_SGS * grad_u, Viscosity_SGS * StrainRateTensor, and the last equation with the error correction terms, and help me understand why the form given in the documentation is used.
Thanks!

@gridley, I wonder if you can help with this? Having thought about it some more, I'm thinking that all these additional terms are related to changes in volume and therefore disappear for the incompressible case. I would be grateful if you can confirm whether my understanding is correct or if there's something else going on which I have missed!

Hey, so, this was just a little experiment for a class project that I included in a PR as a starting point for others. It is completely unvalidated, because I found MOOSE to be too slow for running 3D LES just given the lack of ability to do efficient preconditioning for this type of system. I had based the formulation off of what was given in this paper:
Bouffanais, Roland, Michel O. Deville, and Emmanuel Leriche. “Large-Eddy Simulation of the Flow in a Lid-Driven Cubical Cavity.” Physics of Fluids 19, no. 5 (May 1, 2007): 055108. https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2723153.
And yeah, my attention was only being paid to incompressible flows at the time. In that paper, you can see that the eddy viscosity is indeed just summed with the normal viscosity. Also, you have to mind that what's implemented in the kernel is the weak form, so gradient multiplied by the test function gradient corresponds to a laplacian in the strong form PDE.

What is implemented in the INSADSmagorinskyEddyViscosity is equation 4 of the paper Gavin linked to.
The normal viscosity can be added with an INSADMomentumViscous kernel.
The Reynolds stresses are simplified in the incompressible Smagorinsky model
Thanks @GiudGiud !

Ok, so to make sure I'm understanding this correctly:
Whilst the Smagorinsky model uses the concept of turbulent viscosity, it does not use the equation for $\tau_{SGS}$ in my post above.
Rather, when equation 4 in the cited paper for $\nu_{SGS}$ is derived, this is done in such a way that $\nu_{SGS}$ can simply be added to the usual viscosity in the Navier-Stokes momentum equations, and hence model the effect of sub-grid scale turbulent stresses.
@gridley, regarding MOOSE running 3D LES slowly - is this specifically for LES simulations, or is this a general comment about the Navier-Stokes module? Possibly unrelated if the issues are to do with preconditioning rather than mesh resolution requirements, but I've been mulling over how to an appropriate grid size, given the absence of a k-epsilon or k-omega model to estimate the integral length scale.
Thanks both for your help in clarifying what's currently implemented - hopefully this will enable me to properly include some damping functions for the existing kernel.

@Eilloo are you interested in using finite volume NS instead of FE?
We have a K-epsilon turbulence model there. It's not merged yet, it's in this PR
#22228
Scalable performance on NS simulations can only be achieved with field splits so far. We are in the process of deploying:

a fix for vector variables field splits (was 3D LES using vector variables?) #22643
some working field splits for NSFV #22405

Beyond field split preconditioning of the fully coupled problem, we are also deploying segregated solution schemes (as opposed to fully coupled) in a single application #22699

I'm trying to stay in FE as the plan is to look at fluid-structure interactions, and therefore make use of the FSI module in MOOSE. From my scouring around the documentation and forums, I gather coupling between finite element and finite volume, as well as mesh morphing in finite volume, are both difficult problems to get around?
This is one of my motivations to try developing the existing turbulence model in FE to get some more accurate results at higher Reynolds numbers.
That said, it's great to hear that k-epsilon is on its way in FVNS, as I am also exploring some finite volume bits in the background.
Regarding performance scaling, that's good to know. Most of my simulations thus far have been relatively simple 2D cases, but I will experiment with field splits as these become more complex and start taking longer to run.

node.title: VPP that prints QP values of AuxVariables and coordinates?
node.bodyText: I'd like to get text output from a MOOSE run that shows my AuxVariable values at all quadrature points along with the coordinates. Could be for all times or each time step in a separate file or whatever. I don't see any VectorPostprocessors that do this, but MaterialVectorPostprocessor is close if I make a ParsedMaterial from my AuxVariable, but a) it is only for specified elements and b) does not print the coordinates. Could that VPP be modified to do this or is there a better way? Through Paraview perhaps?
Oh I forgot about Sampler1DReal. Why is that in the Thermal Hydraulics module?

no idea.
Another sampler for variables is the ElementValueSampler, but that does not Qps just centroids
Would it be easy to add to or inherit from ElementValueSampler to have it work at quadrature points?
I d expect it to be easier from the MaterialVPP but ElementValueSampler could also be an option
ElementValueSampler seems closer since it already prints coordinates and runs on all elements. Would it be difficult to add a qp loop in there? I'm not sure how that Sampler class works.

node.title: Tensor Mechanics Master Action Outputs not compatible with the new system.
node.bodyText:
I recently discovered that some tensor mechanics generate outputs arguments in the master action block do not work when used with the new system for tensor mechanics.
For example, vonmises_stress does not work, as it is hard coded to calculate the vonmises value using the global tensor 'stress'. However, when using the new system, stresses are stored in the global tensor 'cauchy_stress'. This means to extract vonmises stresses you must use a rank two aux kernel.
This is not a huge issue, but it would be good if the master action could intelligently switch between looking for stress and cauchy stress depending on the system in use.
@bwspenc who else should we tag to get some feedback / opinions on this
This issue does exist and should be fixed.
@reverendbedford @dschwen

Yeah, this is an issue. We have long had a convention that the property named stress was the Cauchy stress. The developers of the new system were explicit in their naming of the stress because there were multiple types of stress computed. A few options:

Change the name of cauchy_stress to stress in the new system
Change the name of stress to cauchy_stress in the old system
Have both the new and old system compute properties called cauchy_stress and stress

I think option 1 would be the easiest, but maybe that's not the best route, because there's certainly something to be said for being explicit in the naming. I think this is my favorite, though.
Option 2 would cause huge amounts of breakage. Also, we have to think about how far to carry the convention of explicitly spelling out the stress type. Would we call it vonmises_cauchy_stress, for instance?
Option 3 would require extra compute resources and would potentially be confusing.
I'm interested in what others think.
I think it has to be option 1, unless we can think of something else entirely.

Rest of MOOSE is aiming to be more explicit and less vague in their names. Having things named vaguely or imprecisely hurts the next generation of users and developers as they have to learn the imprecision, often through a mistake and its consequences

@GiudGiud I totally appreciate the desire to define things precisely. It's always a challenge finding the right balance between that and usability. I'm not sure what the right answer is here. We need to think through the full consequences of whatever path we choose.

How about defining a new parameter in the TM action called "output_stress_measure" or something like that which defaults to "stress" if new_system = false, and to "cauchy_stress" if new_system = true.
@hugary1995 I like that idea -- something along the lines of that could be a good solution.
Okay, that sounds like the end of the bike shedding time. I can handle this when I get a chance if no one beats me to it. #22776
Marking this as solved pending a fix being implemented, thanks for the quick response 👍

node.title: LibMesh Update 2022.10.05
node.bodyText:
A new libMesh has made its way to the MOOSE master branch. For those using the conda packages, please perform
mamba update --all

in your MOOSE conda environment. The appropriate moose-libmesh package version should be 2022.10.05. For those using the libMesh submodule, please run in the moose/scripts directory
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

after updating your copy of MOOSE.

Thank you for posting this information here.
I tried to do my regular MOOSE update yesterday, which failed.  I knew from previous experience that this is often because of an update to libmesh.  So I tried my usual method to update that which is:
mamba update moose-libmesh=2022.10.05
But MOOSE now doesn't seem to run or update at all.  It seems to be broken.
When I enter "mamba update --all", I get the following:
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/eshelton/mambaforge3/bin/mamba", line 11, in <module> sys.exit(main()) File "/home/eshelton/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 914, in main from conda.common.compat import ensure_text_type, init_std_stream_encoding ImportError: cannot import name 'init_std_stream_encoding' from 'conda.common.compat' (/home/eshelton/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/conda/common/compat.py)
Can you advise what I need to do to recover MOOSE with the latest version of libmesh?

It looks like mamba is having issues.
I d remove the moose environment, remove mamba, then reinstall from scratch
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
All seems to be reinstalled and running again now.  Many thanks for your help.

I know I'm a little late but I had this issue last month and for me the reason was that mamba was out of date with conda because running conda update --all within the MOOSE environment doesn't update mamba, so my mamba version was way outdated compared to everything else and it stopped working. The suggested fix was to just update mamba in the base environment, which is not mentioned in the MOOSE install/update instructions or troubleshooting page, but it worked perfectly and I didn't have to reinstall anything. Figured this might help someone else in the future.

node.title: unable to use CartesianMeshGenerator
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I've just started learning MOOSE, so my question may be silly.
I have created an application to run the mug example (ex01) and it ran without a problem.
I used the same application to run the following lines (from https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/CartesianMeshGenerator.html:)
[Mesh]
  [./cmg]
    type = CartesianMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    dx = '1.5 2.4 0.1'
    dy = '1.3 0.9'
    dz = '0.4 0.5 0.6 0.7'
    ix = '2 1 1'
    iy = '2 3'
    iz = '1 1 1 1'
    subdomain_id = '0 1 1
                    2 2 2

                    3 4 4
                    5 5 5

                    0 1 1
                    2 2 2

                    3 4 4
                    5 5 5
                    '
  [../]
[]

It doesn't work. here is the message error:


*** ERROR ***
/mnt/c/users/pjean/MOOSE_INSTAL_FILES/02-mesh_generation/cmg_try.i contains Windows(DOS) line endings which are not supported.

Stack frames: 10
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: void mooseError<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > >(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&&)
3: MooseUtils::checkFileReadable(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, bool, bool, bool)
4: Parser::parse(std::vector<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::allocator<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > > > const&)
5: MooseApp::setupOptions()
6: MooseApp::run()
7: main
8: __libc_start_main
9: ../cat/cat-opt(+0x23ef) [0x556f5e5873ef]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

Does anybody know why it is not working?
Thanks!
P.

Hello
The issue is due to some extra characters that windows inserts into files and the MOOSE parser doesnt support.
You may use dos2unix to remove these characters, or any advanced IDE will also have an option to remove them.
Where did you edit the file? on a windows text editor then running them from WSL?
The syntax for the cartesianMeshGenerator seems correct otherwise.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
thank you for your answer. I used dos2unix and it worked :)!
Cheers,
Pierre

node.title: Can I use FSP for EigenValue calculation
node.bodyText:
Hi, experts.



I'm using InversePowerMethod to do some eigenvalue calculation. When the problem size is large, the computational cost of using SMP will be high. So can FSP be used in the eigenvalue calculation of MOOSE (just like the steady or transient calculation)？



I found that compared to InversePowerMethod, MOOSE now recommends Eigenvalue for eigenvalue calculation. I now have an Executioner for InversePowerMethod that I did before. But when I wanted to transform it from InversePowerMethod to Eigenvalue, I found some differences between InversePowerMethod and Eigenvalue. For example, in InversePowerMethod, I will set xdiff and bnorm, but these are not available in Eigenvalue. How can this be solved?

Hello


I dont know that it's been used for eigenvalue calculations


This will require additional development to provide these settings in our new eigenvalue executioner.


Guillaume

For 2 you should be able to reproduce the previous behavior using the

normalization postprocessor to indicate what computes the norm
normal_factor : the norm to reach after normalization
@YaqiWang will know more than me about normalization of the output of the eigenvalue executioner

I have used Eigenvalue and NonlinearEigen. NonlinearEigen can run but the convergence is not good, and Eigenvalue can't run.
# [Executioner]
#   type = NonlinearEigen
#   free_power_iterations = 6

#   normalization = 'powernorm'
#   normal_factor = 21230

#   bx_norm = 'bnorm'
#   k0 = 1.3
#   l_max_its = 200
#   nl_abs_tol = 1e-7

#   solve_type = 'NEWTON'
#   petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
#   petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
#   petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO               superlu_dist'

#   line_search = none
#   automatic_scaling = true
# []

# [Executioner]
#   type = Eigenvalue
#   free_power_iterations = 6

#   normalization = 'powernorm'
#   normal_factor = 21230

#   initial_eigenvalue = 1
#   l_max_its = 200
#   nl_abs_tol = 1e-7

#   solve_type = 'NEWTON'
#   petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason -ksp_converged_reason -snes_linesearch_monitor'
#   petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
#   petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO               superlu_dist'

#   line_search = none
#   automatic_scaling = true
# []

So I think I'd better use InversePowerMethod.

When I use Eigenvalue, I meet a Segmentation fault (signal 11).


I want to know if this change has been merged into the latest moose, I want to wait until it is merged to update moose and do some FSP testing.

node.title: This very very very easy question of tensor mechanics cannot get converge...
node.bodyText:
I try to set a rigid body. I only set a fix boundary condition and a pressure. The mesh volume is only 1. But this so easy question cannot get converge....Could anyone explain the reason?
The input file is here.

The question is here

and the output is
0 Nonlinear |R| = 5.000000e+05
      0 Linear |R| = 5.000000e+05
      1 Linear |R| = 7.816385e+02
      2 Linear |R| = 2.736129e+02
      3 Linear |R| = 4.362376e+01
      4 Linear |R| = 3.015174e+01
      5 Linear |R| = 1.570861e-02
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0

Input file:
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]
[Mesh]
  [file]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = fangkuaiceshi.exo
  []
[]
[BCs]
  [gudingx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'XIA'
    value = 0
  []
  [gudingy]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'XIA'
    value = 0
  []
  [gudingz]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'XIA'
    value = 0
  []
  [Pressure]
    [LINE]
      boundary = 'SHANG'
      function = 1e6
    []
  []
[]
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'vonmises_stress stress_xx stress_yy 
    stress_zz stress_xy stress_yz stress_zx'
    strain = FINITE
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor_steel]
    youngs_modulus = 1e100 #Pa
    poissons_ratio = 1e-10
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
  [../]
  [./stress1]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  nl_max_its = 100
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]


and mesh:
fangkuaiceshi.zip

If I change the Young modulus to 1e10 from 1e100, it will converge. I do not know the reason.
Or how can I simulate a rigid body in MOOSE Multiphysics?

node.title: Can I set the heat source at the boundary?
node.bodyText:
Hello, guys.
Now I want to simulate the PC radiator (for cooling) using MOOSE, but I have some trouble setting the boundary condition.
To confirm the temperature change on the hot side, I couldn't set the temp BCs at the hot side (bottom).
(because If I set the boundary condition, the temperature doesn't change at the simulation!)
So, I want to set the heat source at this simulation, but I don't know how can I make the heat source only on the bottom hot side.
When I used the "Heat Source" at the kernel, all of the mesh make the volumetric heat, and my plan would fail.
Please let me know how I can set the heat source at the boundary.
Thanks a lot for your kindness!

Ham

I think you may be looking for ConvectiveHeatFluxBC or a Neumann BC.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/ConvectiveHeatFluxBC.html
Agreed. The boundary conditions will let you specify a heat flux, either from a heat source or towards the heat sink.

node.title: how to build a pure convection question

node.bodyText: Did you override computeQpJacobian? If not, the Jacobian will be entirely zero (except the body force term), hence the error.
thanks!
If for whatever reason you don't want to derive/code the Jacobian, you can use AD.

We strongly recommend you use AD to develop your kernel. Please see this documentation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/automatic_differentiation/#!
you will need to inherit the ADKernel, and you will need to retrieve properties as AD
